properties.name: anchor-name
properties.appliesTo: all elements that generate a principal box

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect.

values.name: <dashed-ident>#
values.prose: If the element generates a principal box, the element is an anchor element, with a list of anchor names as specified. Each anchor name is a tree-scoped name. Otherwise, the property has no effect.

properties.name: inset-area
properties.appliesTo: positioned elements with a default anchor element

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect.

values.name: <inset-area-span>
values.prose: Behaves as <inset-area-span> / all, filling the entire row/column of the grid indicated by the specified value.

values.name: <inset-area-span> [ / <inset-area-span> ]?
values.prose: If the element does not have a default anchor element, or is not an absolutely-positioned element, this value has no effect. Otherwise, the two spans define a rectangular region of the inset-area grid, and have the following effects: Any auto inset properties compute to the appropriate value to match the rectangular region. The normal value for the self-alignment properties behaves as either start, end, or anchor-center, depending on the positioning of the region, to give a good default alignment for the positioned element. See § 3.1.1 Resolving <inset-area-span>s for details on both of these effects. If the two <inset-area-span>s do not define a valid region, this property is invalid.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned element has a default anchor element, then it is aligned so as to center itself over the default anchor element in the appropriate axis. If this alignment would cause it to overflow its inset-modified containing block in the appropriate axis, it instead is aligned flush with the side that it would have overflowed; if it would overflow both sides, it’s instead aligned as for start.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned element has a default anchor element, then it is aligned so as to center itself over the default anchor element in the appropriate axis. If this alignment would cause it to overflow its inset-modified containing block in the appropriate axis, it instead is aligned flush with the side that it would have overflowed; if it would overflow both sides, it’s instead aligned as for start.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned element has a default anchor element, then it is aligned so as to center itself over the default anchor element in the appropriate axis. If this alignment would cause it to overflow its inset-modified containing block in the appropriate axis, it instead is aligned flush with the side that it would have overflowed; if it would overflow both sides, it’s instead aligned as for start.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned element has a default anchor element, then it is aligned so as to center itself over the default anchor element in the appropriate axis. If this alignment would cause it to overflow its inset-modified containing block in the appropriate axis, it instead is aligned flush with the side that it would have overflowed; if it would overflow both sides, it’s instead aligned as for start.

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect; the element does not use a position fallback list.

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: If there is a @position-fallback rule with a name matching the specified ident, then the element uses that position fallback list. Otherwise, this value has no effect.

values.name: normal
values.prose: The element uses its normal (scroll-adjusted, inset-modified) containing block to determine if it’s overflowing for the purpose of selecting a position fallback list entry.

atrules.name: @position-fallback
atrules.prose: The @position-fallback rule defines a position fallback list with a given name, specifying one or more sets of positioning properties inside of @try blocks that will be applied to an element, with each successive one serving as fallback if the previous would cause the element to partially or fully overflow its containing block.

atrules.name: @try
atrules.prose: The @position-fallback rule defines a position fallback list with a given name, specifying one or more sets of positioning properties inside of @try blocks that will be applied to an element, with each successive one serving as fallback if the previous would cause the element to partially or fully overflow its containing block.

values.name: <inset-area-span>
values.value: [ start || end || center ] | [ self-start || self-end || center ] | [ top || bottom || center ] | [ left || right || center ] | [ x-start || x-end || center ] | [ y-start || y-end || center ] | [ x-self-start || x-self-end || center ] | [ y-self-start || y-self-end || center ] | all

values.name: all
values.prose: All three regions of that axis, spanning the entire breadth of the containing block.

values.name: start
values.prose: Any single keyword refers just to that region in the axis. Like in anchor(), the plain logical keywords (start, end, etc) refer to the writing mode of the element’s containing block. The x-start/etc determine their direction in the same way, but in the specified physical axis. The "self" logical keyword (self-start, x-self-end, etc) are identical, but refer to the element’s own writing mode.

values.name: end
values.prose: Any single keyword refers just to that region in the axis. Like in anchor(), the plain logical keywords (start, end, etc) refer to the writing mode of the element’s containing block. The x-start/etc determine their direction in the same way, but in the specified physical axis. The "self" logical keyword (self-start, x-self-end, etc) are identical, but refer to the element’s own writing mode.

values.name: anchor()
values.prose: An absolutely-positioned element can use the anchor() function as a value in its inset properties to refer to the position of one or more anchor elements. The anchor() function resolves to a <length>.

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: Specifies the anchor name it will look for. This name is a tree-scoped reference.

values.name: implicit
values.prose: Selects the implicit anchor element defined for the element, if possible.

values.name: inside
values.prose: Resolves to one of the anchor element’s sides, depending on which inset property it’s used in. inside refers to the same side as the inset property (attaching the element to the "inside" of the anchor), while outside refers to the opposite.

values.name: outside
values.prose: Resolves to one of the anchor element’s sides, depending on which inset property it’s used in. inside refers to the same side as the inset property (attaching the element to the "inside" of the anchor), while outside refers to the opposite.

values.name: top
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor element.

values.name: right
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor element.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor element.

values.name: left
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor element.

values.name: start
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor element in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned element (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned element’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: end
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor element in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned element (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned element’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: self-start
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor element in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned element (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned element’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: self-end
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor element in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned element (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned element’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: <percentage>
values.prose: Refers to a position a corresponding percentage between the start and end sides, with 0% being equivalent to start and 100% being equivalent to end. center is equivalent to 50%.

values.name: center
values.prose: Refers to a position a corresponding percentage between the start and end sides, with 0% being equivalent to start and 100% being equivalent to end. center is equivalent to 50%.

values.name: <anchor-side>
values.value: inside | outside | top | left | right | bottom | start | end | self-start | self-end | <percentage> | center

values.name: anchor-size()
values.prose: An absolutely-positioned element can use the anchor-size() function in its sizing properties to refer to the size of one or more anchor elements. The anchor-size() function resolves to a <length>.

values.name: width
values.prose: The physical <anchor-size> keywords (width and height) refer to the width and height, respectively, of the target anchor element. Unlike anchor(), there is no restriction on having to match axises; for example, width: anchor-size(--foo height); is valid.

values.name: height
values.prose: The physical <anchor-size> keywords (width and height) refer to the width and height, respectively, of the target anchor element. Unlike anchor(), there is no restriction on having to match axises; for example, width: anchor-size(--foo height); is valid.

values.name: block
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the element (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the element’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: inline
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the element (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the element’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: self-block
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the element (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the element’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: self-inline
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the element (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the element’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: <anchor-size>
values.value: width | height | block | inline | self-block | self-inline
